1.verse: Prologue -Chapter 1 -Set Apart for the Gospel. -Paul, a servant of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle and set apart for the service of the gospel

2.verse: that God promised beforehand through his Prophets in the holy Scriptures,

3.verse: the gospel concerning his Son who according to the flesh was descended from David,

4.verse: and who according to the Spirit of holiness was proclaimed to be the Son of God in power by his resurrection from the dead: Jesus Christ our Lord.

5.verse: Through him we have received grace and our apostolic commission to proclaim the obedience of faith among all the Gentiles for the sake of his name.

6.verse: And you are among those who are called to belong to Jesus Christ.

7.verse: To all of you who are God’s beloved in Rome and called to be saints: grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

8.verse: Thanksgiving and Prayer. -First of all, I give thanks to my God through Jesus Christ for all of you because your faith has been proclaimed throughout the world.

9.verse: For God, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of his Son, is the witness on my behalf that I remember you constantly in my prayers,

10.verse: always asking that by God’s will I may somehow be granted my desire of coming to visit you.

11.verse: For I am longing to see you so that I may bestow on you some spiritual gift to strengthen you—

12.verse: or, rather, so that we may be mutually encouraged by each other’s faith, both yours and mine.

13.verse: I want you to be aware, brethren, that I have often planned to visit you (although until now I have been prevented from doing so) because it has been my desire to achieve some harvest among you as I have among other Gentiles.

14.verse: I have an obligation to Greeks and non-Greeks alike, to both the educated and the ignorant.

15.verse: Thus, I am ready to preach the gospel also to you who are in Rome.

16.verse: The Gospel of God -Power of Salvation for All Believers. -For I am not ashamed of the gospel, since it is the power of God that offers salvation to everyone who has faith—to Jews first, and then to Gentiles as well.

17.verse: In it the righteousness of God is revealed, beginning in faith and established in faith. As it is written: “The one who is righteous will live through faith.”

18.verse: Justification through Faith in Jesus -The World in the Wrath of God -Exchanging the Truth of God for a Lie. -The wrath of God is being revealed from heaven against all the ungodliness and wickedness of those who by their wickedness suppress the truth.

19.verse: For that which can be known about God is clearly evident to them because God has revealed it plainly to them.

20.verse: Ever since the creation of the world the invisible attributes of God’s eternal power and divine nature have been clearly understood and perceived through the things he has made.Therefore, the conduct of these people is inexcusable.

21.verse: Despite knowing God, they refused to honor him as God or give thanks to him. As a result, their speculations became foolish and their uncomprehending hearts became darkened.

22.verse: Although they claimed to be wise, in reality they became fools,

23.verse: exchanging the glory of the immortal God for images fashioned in the likeness of a mortal man or birds or fourfooted animals or reptiles.

24.verse: Therefore, God abandoned them in the sinful lusts of their hearts to impurity and the mutual degradation of their bodies.

25.verse: They exchanged the truth of God for a lie and offered worship and service to the creature rather than to the Creator, who is blessed forever. Amen.

26.verse: That is why God abandoned them to their shameful passions. Their women exchanged natural intercourse for unnatural practices.

27.verse: Likewise, men gave up natural relations with women and were consumed with passion for one another. Men committed shameful acts with men and received in their own persons the fitting penalty for their perversion.

28.verse: Furthermore, since these people did not see fit to acknowledge God, he abandoned them to their depraved way of thinking and to all types of vile behavior.

29.verse: As a result, they are filled with every kind of wickedness, evil, greed, and malice. Reveling in envy, murder, strife, deceit, and malice, they are gossips,

30.verse: slanderers, God-haters, insolent, arrogant, and boastful, as they devise new ways of doing evil and rebel against their parents.

31.verse: They are senseless, faithless, heartless, and ruthless.

32.verse: Although they are fully cognizant of God’s decree that those who behave in this way deserve to die, they not only do these things themselves but also praise all those who engage in such conduct.

1.verse: Chapter 2 -Judging Is Inexcusable. -Therefore, you have no excuse, whoever you may be, when you pass judgment on others. For in judging others you condemn yourself, since you are doing the same things.

2.verse: We are all aware that God’s judgment on those who commit such deeds is just.

3.verse: How can you then suppose that you will escape the judgment of God for doing such things when you are condemning those who perform the same things?

4.verse: How can you despise the riches of God’s kindness and forbearance and patience? How can you fail to realize that his kindness is meant to lead you to repentance?

5.verse: By your obstinate refusal to repent you are storing up retribution for yourself on the day of wrath when God’s righteous judgment will be revealed.

6.verse: For God will repay everyone in accordance with what his deeds deserve.

7.verse: To those who seek after glory and honor and immortality by persevering in good works, he will grant eternal life.

8.verse: But for those who are slaves to selfish ambition and follow the path of wickedness and not of truth, wrath and fury will be their lot.

9.verse: There will be affliction and distress for everyone who does evil—Jews first and then Gentiles.

10.verse: However, glory, honor, and peace await everyone who does good—Jews first, and then Gentiles.

12.verse: The Law and Conscience. -All those who have sinned outside the Law will perish outside the Law, and all who sinned under the Law will be judged by the Law.

13.verse: For it is not those who hear the Law who are justified by God; rather, it is those who observe the Law who will be justified.

14.verse: Therefore, when Gentiles, who do not have the Law, act by nature in conformity with the Law, they are a law for themselves, even though they have no Law.

15.verse: They show that the requirements of the Law are inscribed in their hearts; and their own conscience will also bear witness for them, since their conflicting thoughts will accuse or even defend them

16.verse: on the day when, according to the gospel, God will judge the thoughts of all through Jesus Christ.

17.verse: You call yourself a Jew and rely on the Law and are proud of your relationship to God,

18.verse: and you know his will and are able to distinguish between right and wrong because you have been instructed in the Law,

19.verse: and you are confident that you are a guide to the blind, a light for those in darkness,

20.verse: an instructor of the foolish, and a teacher of the simple because in the Law you have the embodiment of knowledge and truth.

21.verse: You, then, who teach others, do you not teach yourself? You who preach against stealing, are you yourself a thief?

22.verse: You who forbid adultery, are you yourself an adulterer? You who abhor idols, do you commit sacrilege?

23.verse: You who boast of the Law, do you dishonor God by breaking it?

24.verse: As it is written, “Because of you the name of God is reviled among the Gentiles.”

25.verse: Circumcision and the Heart. -Circumcision has value if you obey the Law. However, if you break the Law, you have become as if you had never been circumcised.

26.verse: In the same way, if one who is not circumcised keeps the precepts of the Law, will not his uncircumcision be regarded as circumcision?

27.verse: Then the man who is not physically circumcised but nevertheless observes the Law will condemn you who have the written code and circumcision but break the Law.

28.verse: A man is not a Jew who is only one outwardly, nor is true circumcision external and physical.

29.verse: Rather, the Jew is one who is a Jew inwardly, and true circumcision is of the heart—spiritual, not literal. He receives his praise not from human beings but from God.

1.verse: Chapter 3 -The Value of Judaism. -Is there any advantage, therefore, in being a Jew? Or what is the value of circumcision?

2.verse: A great deal in every respect. In the first place, they were entrusted with the words of God.

3.verse: What if some were unfaithful? Will their lack of faith nullify the fidelity of God?

4.verse: By no means! God must be true even if every human being is a liar, as it is written,“That you may be justified in your words,and vindicated when you are judged.”

5.verse: But if our wickedness serves to confirm the righteousness of God, what are we to say? Is God unjust (I speak of him in human terms) to bring retribution upon us?

6.verse: Of course not! For that would imply that God could not judge the world.

7.verse: But if, as a result of my falsehood, God demonstrates his truthfulness, to his greater glory, why am I still being condemned as a sinner?

8.verse: And why not say, as some people slanderously accuse us of proposing, “Let us do evil so that good may result”? Such people deserve their condemnation.

9.verse: The Whole World Guilty before God. -Well, then, are we any better? No, not at all. For we have already charged that both Jews and Gentiles alike are all under the power of sin.

10.verse: As it is written,“There is no one who is righteous,not even one.

11.verse: There is no one who has understanding,there is no one who seeks God.

12.verse: All have turned away;together they have become worthless.There is no one who shows kindness,not even one.

13.verse: Their throats are open graves;they use their tongues to deceive.The venom of vipers is on their lips;

14.verse: their mouths are full of cursing and bitterness.

15.verse: Their feet hasten to shed blood;

16.verse: ruin and misery mark their paths.

17.verse: The way of peace they do not know;

18.verse: there is no fear of God before their eyes.”

19.verse: Now we know that what the Law says is addressed to those who are under the Law, so that every mouth may be silenced and the entire world may be seen as guilty before God.

20.verse: For no one can be regarded as justified in the sight of God by keeping the Law. The Law brings only the consciousness of sin.

21.verse: The Redemption in Jesus Christ -God’s Righteousness through Faith in Jesus Christ. -But now the righteousness of God that is attested by the Law and the Prophets has been manifested apart from law:

22.verse: the righteousness of God through faith in Jesus Christ for all who believe. No distinction has been made.

23.verse: For all have sinned and thereby are deprived of the glory of God,

24.verse: and all are justified by the gift of his grace that is given freely through the redemption in Christ Jesus.

25.verse: God designated him to be a sacrifice of expiation of sin through faith by the shedding of his blood because in his divine forbearance he allowed to be unpunished the sins previously committed.

26.verse: He thus demonstrated his righteousness in the present time so that he might show himself to be just as the one who justifies anyone who has faith in Jesus.

27.verse: Justification through Faith Apart from the Works of the Law. -What reason then does one have to boast? It is excluded! By works of the Law? No, rather by the law of faith.

28.verse: For we maintain that one is justified by faith apart from the works of the Law.

29.verse: Is God the God only of the Jews? Is he not also the God of the Gentiles? Yes, he is the God of the Gentiles too,

30.verse: since there is only one God, and he will justify both the circumcised and the uncircumcised on the basis of their faith.

31.verse: Are we thereby nullifying the Law by this faith? By no means! On the contrary, we are upholding the Law.

1.verse: Abraham Justified through Faith -Chapter 4 -Justified through Faith, Not Works. -What then are we to say about Abraham, our ancestor according to the flesh?

2.verse: If Abraham was justified by the works he did, he has good reason to boast, but not in the eyes of God.

3.verse: For what does Scripture say? “Abraham placed his faith in God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.”

4.verse: Now when a man works, his wages are not regarded as a gift but as something that is due to him.

5.verse: However, when someone who does not work places his faith in one who justifies the godless, such faith is reckoned as righteousness.

6.verse: In the same way, David speaks of the blessedness of the one to whom God attributes righteousness apart from works:

7.verse: “Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgivenand whose sins are blotted out.

8.verse: Blessed is the manto whom the Lord imputes no guilt.”

9.verse: Justified before Being Circumcised. -Is this blessedness granted only to the circumcised, or does it apply to the uncircumcised as well? We have asserted that Abraham’s faith “was credited to him as righteousness.”

10.verse: How was it credited? Was it when he was circumcised or uncircumcised? Not when he was circumcised, but when he was uncircumcised.

11.verse: Abraham received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while he was still uncircumcised. In this way, he was the father of all who believe without being circumcised and who thus have righteousness credited to them.

12.verse: Therefore, he is the father of the circumcised who have not only received circumcision but also follow that path of faith traversed by Abraham before he was circumcised.

13.verse: Justified Apart from the Law. -It was not through the Law that Abraham and his descendants received the promise that he would inherit the world, but through the righteousness of faith.

14.verse: If those who live by the Law are the heirs, faith is null and the promise is void.

15.verse: For the Law produces only wrath, and where no Law exists, there cannot be any violation.

16.verse: Therefore, the promise depends on faith, so that it may be a free gift and the promise may be guaranteed to all descendants, not only to the adherents of the Law but also to those who share the faith of Abraham. For he is the father of all of us,

17.verse: as it is written, “I have made you the father of many nations,” in the sight of God in whom he believed, the God who gives life to the dead and calls into being what does not exist.

18.verse: The Power of Faith. -Though he hoped against hope, he believed that he would become the father of many nations, in fulfillment of the promise, “So shall your descendants be.”

19.verse: His faith was not shaken when he considered his own body, which was as good as dead (for he was about one hundred years old), and the barren womb of Sarah.

20.verse: Confident in the promise of God, he did not doubt in unbelief; rather, he was strengthened in his faith and gave glory to God,

21.verse: remaining fully convinced that he was able to fulfill his pledge.

22.verse: Therefore, his faith “was credited to him as righteousness.”

23.verse: “It was credited to him” was not written with Abraham alone in mind.

24.verse: This was also meant for us as well, to whom it will be credited as righteousness—for us who believe in him who raised from the dead Jesus our Lord

25.verse: who was handed over to death for our sins and who was raised to life for our justification.

1.verse: Faith, the Riches of Life -Chapter 5 -At Peace with God -Hope Does Not Disappoint. -Therefore, now that we have been justified by faith, we are at peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,

2.verse: through whom by faith we have been given access to this grace in which we now live, and we rejoice in the hope of the glory of God.

3.verse: And not only that, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we realize that suffering develops perseverance,

4.verse: and perseverance produces character, and character produces hope.

5.verse: Such hope will not be doomed to disappointment, because the love of God has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit that has been given to us.

6.verse: Reconciliation Already Obtained. -At the appointed time, while we were still helpless, Christ died for the ungodly.

7.verse: Indeed, it is seldom that anyone will die for a just person, although perhaps for a good person someone might be willing to die.

8.verse: Thus, God proved his love for us in that while we were still sinners Christ died for us.

9.verse: And so, now that we have been justified by Christ’s blood, how much more certainly will we be saved through him from divine retribution.

10.verse: For if, while we were enemies, we were reconciled to God through the death of his Son, how much more certain it is that, having been reconciled, we shall be saved by his life.

11.verse: And not only that, but we now even trust exultantly in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have already been granted reconciliation.

12.verse: Adam and Christ—Sin and Grace -Humanity’s Sin through Adam. -Therefore, sin entered the world as the result of one man, and death as a result of sin, and thus death has afflicted the entire human race inasmuch as everyone has sinned.

13.verse: Sin was already in the world before there was any Law, even though sin is not reckoned when there is no Law.

14.verse: Nevertheless, death reigned over all from Adam to Moses, even over those who had not sinned by disobeying a command, as did Adam who prefigured the one who was to come.

15.verse: Grace and Life through Christ. -However, the gift is not like the transgression. For if the transgression of one man led to the death of the many, how much greater was the overflowing effect of the grace of God and the gift of the one man Jesus Christ that has abounded for the many.

16.verse: The gift of God cannot be compared with the sin of the one man. For the one sin resulted in the judgment that brought condemnation, but the gift freely given after many transgressions resulted in justification.

17.verse: For if, because of one man’s transgression, death reigned through that man, how much more shall those who receive the abundance of grace and the gift of righteousness come to reign in life through the one man Jesus Christ.

18.verse: Therefore, just as one man’s transgression brought condemnation for all, so one man’s righteous act resulted in justification and life for all.

19.verse: For just as through the disobedience of one man the many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one man the many will be made righteous.

20.verse: Purpose of the Law. -When the Law was added, offenses multiplied; but the increase in sins was far exceeded by the increase in grace.

21.verse: Hence, as sin’s reign resulted in death, so the grace of God also might reign through righteousness resulting in eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.

1.verse: Death and Life with Christ -Chapter 6 -Baptized in Christ Jesus. -What then shall we say? Should we persist in sin in order that grace may abound?

2.verse: Of course not! We have died to sin. How can we live in it any longer?

3.verse: Do you not know that all of us who have been baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?

4.verse: Through that baptism into his death we were buried with him, so that, just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, so we too might begin to live a new life.

5.verse: For if we have been united with him in a death like his, we shall also be united with him in his resurrection.

6.verse: We know that our old self was crucified with him, so that our sinful body might be destroyed and we might no longer be enslaved to sin.

7.verse: For whoever has died has been freed from sin.

8.verse: However, if we have died with Christ, we believe that we shall also live with him.

9.verse: We know that Christ, once raised from the dead, will never die again. Death no longer has power over him.

10.verse: When he died, he died to sin once and for all. However, the life he lives, he lives for God.

11.verse: In the same way, you must regard yourselves as being dead to sin and alive for God in Christ Jesus.

12.verse: Therefore, do not allow sin to reign over your mortal body and make you obey its desires.

13.verse: Nor should you present any part of your body as an instrument for wickedness leading to sin. Rather, present yourselves to God as having been raised from death to life and the parts of your body to God as instruments for righteousness.

14.verse: For sin is no longer to have any power over you, since you are not under the Law but under grace.

15.verse: A Slave of Righteousness. -What then? Should we sin because we are not under the Law but under grace? Of course not!

16.verse: Do you not know that if you offer yourself as an obedient slave, you are the slave of the one you obey—either of sin, which leads to death, or of obedience, which leads to righteousness?

17.verse: Once you were slaves of sin, but, thanks be to God, you have become obedient in your heart to that pattern of teaching to which you have been delivered.

18.verse: Now, having been set free from sin, you have become slaves of righteousness.

19.verse: I am speaking in human terms because you are still weak human beings. For just as you once offered your bodies as slaves to impurity and to lawlessness leading to greater iniquity, so now present them as slaves to righteousness for sanctification.

20.verse: When you were slaves of sin, you were free from the restraints of righteousness.

21.verse: But what advantage did you get then from the things of which you are now ashamed? For the end of those things is death.

22.verse: However, now that you have been freed from sin and bound to the service of God, the benefit you receive is sanctification, and the end is eternal life.

23.verse: For the wages of sin is death, but the gift freely given by God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.

1.verse: Christ Has Freed Us from the Law -Chapter 7 -The Time of the Law Has Passed. -Are you aware, brethren (for I am certain that you are people who have knowledge of the Law), that a person is bound by the Law only during that person’s lifetime?

2.verse: For example, a woman is bound by the Law to her husband as long as he lives, but if her husband dies, she is released from her husband in regard to the Law.

3.verse: Therefore, she will be judged to be an adulteress if she has relations with another man while her husband is still alive. However, if her husband dies, she is free from that provision of the Law, and if she then has relations with another man, she is not an adulteress.

4.verse: In the same way, brethren, through the body of Christ you have died to the Law and have been set free to belong to another, that is, to the one who rose from the dead in order that we might bear fruit for God.

5.verse: For when we were in the flesh, our sinful passions were aroused by the Law and at work in our bodies, and they bore fruit for death.

6.verse: But now, we are released from the Law, having died to that which held us captive, so that we may serve in the new life of the Spirit in contrast to the old written code.

7.verse: The Function of the Law. -What then should we say? That the Law is sinful? Absolutely not! Yet if it had not been for the Law, I would not have known what sin was. I would not have known what covet is if the Law had not said, “You shall not covet.”

8.verse: But sin seized the opportunity offered by the commandment and produced in me all kinds of covetousness. Apart from the Law, sin is dead.

9.verse: I lived apart from the Law, but when the commandment came, sin came to life,

10.verse: and I died. The commandment that was for life proved to be death for me.

11.verse: For sin, seizing an opportunity offered by the commandment, deceived me, and through it killed me.

12.verse: And so the Law is holy, and the commandment is holy and just and good.

13.verse: Did what is good, then, cause my death? By no means! But in order that sin might be recognized as such, it brought about my death through what is good, and therefore through the commandment sin became completely sinful.

14.verse: Sin and Death. -We clearly understand that the Law is spiritual, but I am unspiritual, sold into slavery to sin.

15.verse: I do not understand my own actions. For I do not do what I want; rather, I do what I hate.

16.verse: Now if I do what I do not want, then I agree that the Law is good.

17.verse: This indicates that it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells in me.

18.verse: For I know that nothing good dwells in me, that is, in my flesh. I have the desire to do what is good, but I cannot do what is good.

19.verse: For I do not do the good I desire; rather, it is the evil I do not desire that I end up doing.

20.verse: Now if I do what I do not desire, it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells in me.

21.verse: I have thus discovered this principle: when I want to do what is good, evil lies close at hand.

22.verse: In my innermost self, I delight in the Law of God,

23.verse: but I perceive in the members of my body another law at war with the Law that I cherish in my mind. Thus, I am made captive to the law of sin that dwells in my members.

24.verse: What a wretched man I am! Who will rescue me from this body destined for death?

25.verse: Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord. So then, with my mind I am a slave to the Law of God, but with my flesh to the law of sin.

1.verse: The Spirit of God Dwells in Christians -Chapter 8 -There Is No Longer Any Condemnation. -Hence, there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.

2.verse: For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has set you free from the law of sin and death.

3.verse: That which the Law, weakened by the flesh, was unable to do, God has done. By sending his own Son in the likeness of our sinful nature as a sin offering, he condemned sin in the flesh

4.verse: so that the righteous requirements of the Law might be fulfilled in us who live not according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.

5.verse: Animated by the Spirit and Rendered Children of God. -Those who live according to the flesh fix their attention on the things of the flesh, while those who live according to the Spirit set their thoughts on spiritual things.

6.verse: The desires of the flesh result in death, but the desires of the Spirit result in life and peace.

7.verse: Indeed, the desires of the flesh will be hostile to God, for they do not submit to the Law of God, nor could they do so.

8.verse: Those who live according to the flesh can never be pleasing to God.

9.verse: You, however, do not live according to the flesh but according to the Spirit, since the Spirit of God dwells in you. Anyone who does not possess the Spirit of Christ cannot belong to him.

10.verse: But if Christ is in you, then even though the body is dead as a result of sin, the Spirit is alive in you because of righteousness.

11.verse: If the Spirit of him who raised Jesus from the dead dwells in you, then the one who raised Christ from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies through his Spirit that dwells in you.

12.verse: Consequently, brethren, we are not debtors to the flesh and obliged to live according to the flesh.

13.verse: If you do live according to the flesh, you will die. However, if by the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body, you will live.

14.verse: Those who are led by the Spirit of God are children of God.

15.verse: For you did not receive a spirit of slavery leading to fear; rather, you received the Spirit of adoption, enabling us to cry out, “Abba! Father!”

16.verse: The Spirit himself bears witness with our Spirit that we are children of God.

17.verse: And if we are children, then we are heirs—heirs of God and joint heirs with Christ, provided that we share his sufferings so that we may also share his glory.

18.verse: The Future Glory That Shall Be Revealed. -I consider that the sufferings we presently endure are not worth comparing with the glory to be revealed in us.

19.verse: Indeed, creation itself eagerly awaits the revelation of the children of God.

20.verse: For creation was subjected to frustration, not of its own choice but by the will of the one who subjected it, in the hope

21.verse: that creation itself will be freed from its slavery to corruption and share in the glorious freedom of the children of God.

22.verse: As we know, the entire creation has been groaning in labor pains until now—

23.verse: and not only creation, but we ourselves, who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, groan inwardly as we wait for our adoption as children, the redemption of our bodies.

24.verse: For in hope we were saved. Now to see something does not involve hope. For why should we hope for what we have already seen?

25.verse: But if we hope for what we do not yet see, then we wait for it with patience.

26.verse: In the same way, even the Spirit helps us in our weakness. For we do not know how to pray as we should, but the Spirit himself intercedes for us with sighs that cannot be put into words.

27.verse: And the one who searches hearts knows the mind of the Spirit, because the Spirit intercedes for the saints in accordance with God’s will.

28.verse: We know that God makes all things work together for good for those who love him and who are called according to his purpose.

29.verse: For those whom he foreknew he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son so that he might be the firstborn among many brethren.

30.verse: Those whom he predestined he also called, and those whom he called he also justified, and those whom he justified he also glorified.

31.verse: Who Can Separate Us from the Love of Christ? -What then can we say in response to all this? If God is for us, who can be against us?

32.verse: He did not spare his own Son but gave him up for all of us. How then can he fail also to give us everything else along with him?

33.verse: Who will bring any charge against those whom God has chosen? It is God who acquits.

34.verse: Who will condemn? Christ Jesus, who died, or rather rose again, who is at God’s right hand and intercedes for us?

35.verse: Who then can separate us from the love of Christ? Will hardship, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or danger, or the sword?

36.verse: As it is written,“For your sake we are being slain all day long;we are treated like sheep to be slaughtered.”

37.verse: No, throughout all these things we are conquerors because of him who loved us.

38.verse: For I am convinced that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor present things, nor things to come, nor powers,

39.verse: nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature will be able to separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus our Lord.

1.verse: The Lot of the Jewish People -Chapter 9 -Paul’s Love for Israel. -I am speaking the truth in Christ—I am not lying, as my conscience bears witness for me through the Holy Spirit

2.verse: that I have great sorrow and unending anguish in my heart.

3.verse: I would even be willing to be accursed, cut off from Christ for the sake of my brethren who are my kinsmen according to the flesh.

4.verse: They are Israelites who have the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the Law, the worship, and the promises.

5.verse: To them belong the patriarchs, and from them, according to the flesh, came the Christ, God forever, who is over all. Amen.

6.verse: The Word of God Has Not Proved False. -It is not as though the word of God has proved false. For not all who were Israelites truly belong to Israel,

7.verse: and not all of Abraham’s children are his true descendants. On the contrary, “It is through Isaac that descendants will bear your name.”

8.verse: In other words, it is not through physical descent that people are regarded as children of God. Rather, the children of the promise are those who are counted as descendants.

9.verse: For this is how the promise was worded: “About this time next year I shall return, and Sarah will have a son.”

10.verse: And not only that, but Rebekah became pregnant by one man, her husband Isaac.

11.verse: Yet even before her children had been born or done anything good or bad, in order that God’s purpose of election might prevail,

12.verse: dependent not on human works but on his call, she was told, “The older shall serve the younger.”

13.verse: As it is written,“I loved Jacob,but Esau I hated.”

14.verse: Has God Been Unjust? -What then are we to say to that? Has God been unjust? Of course not!

15.verse: For he says to Moses,“I will have mercyon whomever I will have mercy,and I will have pityon whomever I will have pity.”

16.verse: Therefore, it does not depend on anyone’s will or exertion but on God’s mercy.

17.verse: For Scripture says to Pharaoh, “I have raised you up so that I may display my power in you and that my name may be proclaimed throughout the earth.”

18.verse: Consequently, he shows mercy to whomever he wills, and he hardens the hearts of whomever he wills.

19.verse: In response, you will say to me, “Why then does he still find fault? Who can resist his will?”

20.verse: But who indeed are you, a human being, to argue with God? Can something that is made say to its maker, “Why did you make me like this?”

21.verse: Surely, the potter can mold the clay as he wishes. Does he not have the right to make out of the same lump of clay one vessel for a noble purpose and another for ordinary use?

22.verse: What if God, although wishing to show his wrath and to make known his power, nevertheless with great patience endured the objects of his wrath destined for destruction?

23.verse: He did so in order to make known the riches of his glory to the recipients of his mercy whom he prepared long ago for glory.

24.verse: We are the ones whom he has called not only from the Jews but also from the Gentiles.

25.verse: Witness of the Old Testament. -As indeed he says in Hosea,“Those who were not my peopleI will call ‘my people,’and her who was not belovedI will call ‘beloved.’

26.verse: And in the very placewhere it was said to them,‘You are not my people,’there they shall be calledchildren of the living God.”

27.verse: And Isaiah cries out in regard to Israel:“Though the number of the Israeliteswill be like the sand of the sea,only a remnant of them will be saved.

28.verse: For the sentence of the Lord on the earthwill be executed quickly and with finality.”

29.verse: Isaiah had foretold previously:“If the Lord of hostshad not left us any descendants,we would have become like Sodomand been made like Gomorrah.”

30.verse: A Misguided Zeal. -What then shall we say? That the Gentiles who did not strive for righteousness have achieved it, that is, righteousness based on faith,

31.verse: but that Israel, who did strive for righteousness based on the Law, did not succeed in attaining it?

32.verse: Why did this happen? Because they did not pursue it by faith but on the basis of works. They tripped over the stone that causes one to stumble,

33.verse: as it is written:“Behold, I am laying in Ziona stone that will make people stumbleand a rock that will cause them to fall.But the one who trusts in himwill never be put to shame.”

1.verse: Chapter 10 -Brethren, my heart’s desire and my prayer to God for them is that they may be saved.

2.verse: I can testify to the zeal that they have for God, but it is not based on knowledge.

3.verse: For, being ignorant of the righteousness that comes from God, and thereby seeking to establish their own, they have not submitted themselves to God’s righteousness.

4.verse: For Christ is the fulfillment of the Law for the justification of all who believe.

5.verse: The Word Is Near You. -Concerning the righteousness that comes from the Law, Moses writes, “The person who does these things will attain life by them.”

6.verse: However, the righteousness that comes from faith says, “Do not say in your heart, ‘Who will go up to heaven?’ (that is, to bring Christ down),

7.verse: or ‘Who will descend into the abyss?’ (that is, to bring Christ up from the dead).”

8.verse: But what does it say?“The word is near you,on your lips and in your heart”(that is, the word of faith that we proclaim).

9.verse: If you confess with your lips, “Jesus is Lord,” and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.

10.verse: For one believes in the heart and so is justified, and one confesses with the mouth and so is saved.

11.verse: As Scripture asserts, “No one who believes in him will be put to shame.”

12.verse: For there is no distinction between Jew and Gentile. The same Lord is Lord of all, and his generosity is manifested to all who call upon him.

13.verse: Indeed, “everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.”

14.verse: Not All Have Responded to the Good News. -But how can they call on him if they have not come to believe in him? And how can they believe in someone about whom they have never heard? And how can they hear without someone to preach to them?

15.verse: And how will there be people to preach if they are not sent? As it is written, “How beautiful are the feet of those who proclaim the good news!”

16.verse: However, not all have accepted the good news. As Isaiah says, “Lord, who has believed our message?”

17.verse: So then, faith comes from what is heard, and what is heard comes through the word of Christ.

18.verse: And so I ask: Have they not heard? Indeed, they have:“Their voice has gone out all over the world,and their words to the ends of the earth.”

19.verse: Well then, I ask: Is it possible that Israel failed to understand? First Moses says:“I will make you enviousof those who are not a nation.I will rouse your angeragainst a foolish nation.”

20.verse: And Isaiah boldly states:“I was found by thosewho were not looking for me.I have revealed myself to thosewho never asked for me.”

21.verse: But regarding Israel, he says:“All day long I have stretched forth my handsto a disobedient and rebellious people.”

1.verse: Chapter 11 -The Remnant of Israel. -I ask, then: Has God rejected his people? Of course not! I too am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.

2.verse: God has not rejected his people whom he foreknew. You surely must know what Scripture asserts in the passage about Elijah where he pleads with God against Israel:

3.verse: “Lord, they have killed your Prophets, they have torn down your altars. I alone am left, and they are seeking my life.”

4.verse: What was God’s response to him? “I have spared for myself seven thousand men who have not knelt before Baal.”

5.verse: So too, at the present time, there is a remnant, chosen by grace.

6.verse: But if it is by grace, then it is no longer by works; otherwise grace would no longer be grace.

7.verse: What follows, then? Israel was unable to attain what it was seeking. The elect attained it, but the rest were hardened,

8.verse: as it is written:“God gave them a spirit of lethargy:eyes that could not seeand ears that could not hear,down to this very day.”

9.verse: And David says:“Let their table become a snare and a trap,a stumbling block and a retribution for them.

10.verse: Let their eyes be darkened so that they cannot see,and their backs be bent forever.”

11.verse: A Providential Misstep. -And so I ask: Have they stumbled so that they might fall? By no means! However, through their transgression salvation has come to the Gentiles, and this has stirred them to envy.

12.verse: Now if their transgression results in riches for the world, and their loss results in riches for the Gentiles, how much greater riches will their full participation bring!

13.verse: Now I am addressing you Gentiles. Inasmuch then as I am the apostle to the Gentiles, I glory in my ministry

14.verse: in the hope that it will arouse the jealousy of those who are of my flesh so that some might be saved.

15.verse: For if their rejection leads to the reconciliation of the world, what will their acceptance be but life from the dead?

16.verse: The Gentiles’ Salvation. -If the firstfruits are holy, then so is the whole lump of dough. And if the root is holy, so are the branches.

17.verse: But if some of the branches were broken off, and you, a wild olive shoot, have been grafted in their place to share in the rich root of the olive tree,

18.verse: do not boast over against the branches! If you start to boast, remember that it is not you who support the root but the root that supports you.

19.verse: You will assert, “Branches were broken off so that I might be grafted in.”

20.verse: That is true. They were broken off because of their unbelief, but you hold your place only because of your faith. Therefore, do not rise up in pride but be filled with awe.

21.verse: For if God did not spare the natural branches, he might not spare you either.

22.verse: Therefore, keep in mind the kindness and the severity of God: his severity toward those who fell, but his kindness to you provided that you remain deserving of that kindness. Otherwise, you also will be cut off,

23.verse: while those who do not persist in their unbelief will be grafted in, since God has the power to do so again.

24.verse: For if you have been cut from what is by nature a wild olive tree and grafted contrary to nature into a cultivated one, how much more easily will these natural branches be grafted back into their own olive tree.

25.verse: All Israel Will Be Saved. -I do not want you to be unaware of this mystery, brethren, lest you think yourselves too wise: this hardening that has afflicted Israel will continue only until the full number of the Gentiles has come in.

26.verse: This is how all Israel will be saved, as it is written,“The Deliverer will come out of Zion;he will banish godlessness from Jacob

27.verse: And this will be my covenant with themwhen I take away their sins.”

28.verse: As far as the gospel is concerned, they are enemies for your sake. However, as regards election, they are beloved for the sake of the patriarchs.

29.verse: For the gifts of God and his calling are irrevocable.

30.verse: Just as you who were at one time disobedient to God have now received mercy as a result of their disobedience,

31.verse: so they too have now become disobedient in order that, through the mercy shown to you, they too may receive mercy.

32.verse: For God has imprisoned all in disobedience so that he may show mercy to all.

33.verse: The Judgments of God Are Unfathomable. -Oh, the depth of the riches and wisdom and knowledge of God! How inscrutable are his judgments and how unfathomable his ways!

34.verse: “For who has known the mind of the Lord,or who has been his counselor?

35.verse: Or who has given him anythingin order to receive something in return?”

36.verse: For from him and through him and for him are all things. To him be glory forever. Amen.

1.verse: The Need for Faith in Daily Life -Chapter 12 -The New Life and the True Worship. -Therefore, brethren, I implore you by the mercies of God to offer your bodies as a living sacrifice that is holy and acceptable to God—a spiritual act of worship.

2.verse: Do not be conformed to the world, but be transformed by the renewal of your minds, so that you will be able to discern the will of God and to know what is good and acceptable and perfect.

3.verse: Right Use of the Gifts of the One Body. -Through the grace that God has bestowed upon me, I advise every one of you not to think of yourself too highly, but to regard yourself objectively, based on the measure of faith that God has granted.

4.verse: For just as in one body we have many parts, and the parts do not all have the same function,

5.verse: so we, though many, make up one body in Christ, and individually we are all parts of one another.

6.verse: We all have different gifts according to the grace given to us. If it is a gift of prophecy, we should exercise it in proportion to our faith.

7.verse: If it is a gift of ministry, we should engage in serving others. If it is a gift of teaching, we should teach.

8.verse: If it is a gift of exhortation, we should encourage. Whoever gives alms should do so generously; whoever leads should do so conscientiously; whoever performs acts of mercy should do so cheerfully.

9.verse: A Truly Sincere Love. -Let your love be sincere. Loathe what is evil and hold fast to what is good.

10.verse: Love one another with genuine affection. Esteem others more highly than yourself.

11.verse: Do not be lacking in zeal, but serve the Lord with spiritual fervor.

12.verse: Be joyful in your hope. Be patient in times of affliction. Persevere in prayer.

13.verse: Contribute to the needs of the saints, and practice hospitality.

14.verse: Bless those who persecute you; bless them and do not curse them.

15.verse: Rejoice with those who rejoice; weep with those who weep.

16.verse: Live in harmony with one another. Do not consider yourself to be better than others, but associate with the lowly, and never be conceited.

17.verse: Do not repay anyone evil for evil. Rather, be concerned about doing what is good in the eyes of all.

18.verse: As much as possible, and to the extent of your ability, live in peace with everyone.

19.verse: Dearly beloved, never seek revenge. Leave that to the time of retribution. For it is written, “Vengeance is mine, says the Lord. I will repay.”

20.verse: On the contrary,“If your enemy is hungry, feed him;if he is thirsty, give him something to drink.By doing this,you will heap burning coals on his head.”

21.verse: Do not be conquered by evil, but conquer evil with good.

1.verse: Chapter 13 -Obedience to Authority. -Let everyone submit himself to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which derives from God, and whatever authorities exist have been instituted by God.

2.verse: Consequently, anyone who resists authority is rebelling against what God has appointed, and those who so resist will bring judgment upon themselves.

3.verse: Rulers are a source of fear not to those who do good but rather to those who do evil. Do you wish to be free of fear from someone in authority? Then continue to do what is right and you will receive his approval.

4.verse: For he is acting as God’s representative for your welfare. But if you do what is evil, then be afraid for he does not wear a sword for nothing. People in authority are God’s servants to mete out punishment to wrongdoers.

5.verse: Therefore, you are obliged to submit, not only because of fear of punishment but also because of conscience.

6.verse: That is why you also pay taxes, for the authorities are God’s servants, and they devote themselves to this service.

7.verse: Pay to each person what is rightfully his—taxes to the one to whom taxes are due, tolls to the one to whom tolls are due, respect to the one to whom respect is due, honor to the one to whom honor is due.

8.verse: Love Is the Fulfillment of the Law. -Owe nothing to anyone except the debt of love you owe one another. The one who loves others has fulfilled the Law.

9.verse: “You shall not commit adultery, You shall not kill, You shall not steal, You shall not covet,” and every other commandment are all summed up in this: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”

10.verse: Love cannot result in any harm to the neighbor; therefore, love is the fulfillment of the Law.

11.verse: Live Honestly As in the Light. -Do this knowing that the hour has come. It is time for you to awaken from sleep. For our salvation is nearer to us now than it was when we first began to believe.

12.verse: The night is nearly over, and the day is at hand.Let us therefore cast aside the works of darkness and put on the armor of light.

13.verse: Let us behave honorably as in the day: not in orgies and drunkenness, not in debauchery and licentiousness, not in quarreling and jealousy.

14.verse: Rather, put on the Lord Jesus Christ and allow no opportunity for the flesh to gratify its sinful desires.

1.verse: Chapter 14 -The Weak and the Strong in the Community. -Welcome anyone whose faith is weak, but do not get into arguments about doubts.

2.verse: One person may have the faith to eat any kind of food, whereas a weak person may eat only vegetables.

3.verse: The one who eats everything must not look contemptuously on the one who does not, and the one who abstains must not pass judgment on the one who eats, for God has welcomed both.

4.verse: What right do you have to pass judgment on someone else’s servant? The master will determine whether that servant will stand or fall. But the servant will be upheld, for the Lord has the power to enable him to stand.

5.verse: One person may consider one day to be more sacred than another, while another may judge all days to be alike. Let everyone be convinced in his own beliefs.

6.verse: Whoever observes the day observes it for the Lord. Also, the one who eats, eats in honor of the Lord, since he gives thanks to God, while the one who abstains, abstains in honor of the Lord and thereby also gives thanks to God.

7.verse: None of us lives for himself, and none of us dies for himself.

8.verse: If we live, we live for the Lord, and if we die, we die for the Lord. Therefore, whether we live or die, we are the Lord’s.

9.verse: It was for this reason that Christ died and came to life again: so that he might be Lord of both the dead and the living.

10.verse: Why then do you pass judgment on your brother? Or why do you despise your brother? All of us will have to stand before the judgment seat of God.

11.verse: For it is written,“As I live, says the Lord,every knee shall bow before me,and every tongue shall give praise to God.”

12.verse: Consideration for the Weak Conscience. -So, then, each one of us will have to give an account of himself to God.

13.verse: Therefore, let us cease passing judgment on one another, but rather judge never to put a stumbling block or hindrance in the way of a brother.

14.verse: I know, and am convinced in the Lord Jesus, that nothing is unclean in itself. However, it is unclean for someone who believes it to be unclean.

15.verse: If your brother is seriously offended by what you eat, then you are no longer being guided by love. Do not allow the food that you eat to destroy anyone for whom Christ died.

16.verse: Do not let what you think is good to become what others say is evil.

17.verse: For the kingdom of God is not a matter of food and drink but of righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit.

18.verse: The one who serves Christ in such things is pleasing to God and respected by others.

19.verse: Let us then pursue the ways that lead to peace and mutual edification.

20.verse: Do not destroy the work of God for the sake of food. All food is indeed clean, but it is wrong for you to cause others to fall by what you eat.

21.verse: It is best not to eat meat or drink wine or do anything else that causes your brother to stumble.

22.verse: Whatever faith you have, keep it between yourself and God. Blessed is the one who has no reason to condemn himself because of what he approves.

23.verse: But whoever has doubts is condemned if he eats, because he does not act from faith. Whatever does not proceed from faith is sin.

1.verse: Chapter 15 -Patience and Self-Denial. -Those of us who are strong must resolve to put up with the failings of the weak and not please ourselves.

2.verse: Each of us must consider his neighbor’s good for the purpose of building him up.

3.verse: Even Christ never sought to please himself, but, as it is written, “The insults of those who insult you have fallen upon me.”

4.verse: For everything that was written in the past was written for our instruction, so that by perseverance and the encouragement of the Scriptures, we may continue to have hope.

5.verse: May the God of perseverance and encouragement grant that you may live in harmony with one another, following in the example of Jesus Christ,

6.verse: so that with one mind and one voice you may glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.

7.verse: God’s Fidelity and Mercy. -Therefore, accept one another for the glory of God, just as Christ has accepted you.

8.verse: For I tell you that Christ became a servant of the circumcised to manifest God’s truthfulness by confirming the promises given to the patriarchs

9.verse: and so that the Gentiles might glorify God for his mercy, as it is written:“Therefore, I will praise you among the Gentilesand sing praises to your name.”

10.verse: And again it says:“Rejoice, O Gentiles, with his people.”

11.verse: Further it adds:“Praise the Lord, all you Gentiles,and let all the peoples praise him.”

12.verse: And again Isaiah asserts:“The root of Jesse shall come,the one who will arise to rule the Gentiles;the Gentiles will hope in him.”

13.verse: May the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, so that you may grow rich in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.

14.verse: Epilogue -Apostle to the Gentiles. -Brethren, I myself am convinced that you yourselves are immersed in goodness, filled with all knowledge, and able to instruct one another.

15.verse: Nevertheless, I have written to you rather boldly to refresh your memory in some respects because of the grace given to me by God.

16.verse: He has appointed me to be a minister of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles in the priestly service of the gospel of God, in order that the Gentiles might become an acceptable offering consecrated by the Holy Spirit.

17.verse: In Christ Jesus, then, I have reason to glory in my service of God.

18.verse: I will not dare to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me to lead the Gentiles to obedience to God by word and deed,

19.verse: by the power of signs and wonders, through the power of the Spirit of God.So from Jerusalem and the surrounding area, even as far as Illyricum, I have completed the preaching of the gospel of Christ.

20.verse: Moreover, I have always striven to preach the gospel of Christ where the name of Christ is not known, not wanting to build on someone else’s foundation.

21.verse: Rather, as it is written:“Those who have never been told of him shall see,and those who have never heard of him shall understand.”

22.verse: Paul’s Plans for Traveling—Even to Spain. -That is why I have so often been prevented from coming to you.

23.verse: But now, since there is nothing more to keep me in these regions, and since for a good many years I have desired to visit you,

24.verse: I hope to see you when I am on my way to Spain. Then, after I have enjoyed your company for a while, you can send me on my way there.

25.verse: Presently, however, I am going to Jerusalem to minister to the saints.

26.verse: For Macedonia and Achaia have resolved to make a contribution for the benefit of the poor among the saints in Jerusalem.

27.verse: They were pleased to do so, and indeed they are indebted to them, for if the Gentiles have come to share in their spiritual blessings, they owe it to them to share their material blessings with them.

28.verse: Therefore, when I have completed this task and have delivered the fruit of their generosity to them, I will set out for Spain and visit you along the way.

29.verse: And I am sure that when I come, I shall do so with the full measure of the blessing of Christ.

30.verse: Therefore, I exhort you, brethren, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to join me in my labors by praying to God for me

31.verse: that I may be delivered from the unbelievers in Judea and that my service in Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints there.

32.verse: In that way, I can come to you in joy, if God so wills, and be refreshed together with you.

33.verse: The God of peace be with you all. Amen.

1.verse: Chapter 16 -Recommendation of Phoebe. -I commend to you our sister Phoebe, who is a deaconess of the Church at Cenchreae.

2.verse: Welcome her in the Lord in a manner worthy of the saints, and help her with whatever she may need from you, for she has been a benefactor of many people, including myself.

3.verse: List of Greetings. -Give my greetings to Prisca and Aquila, my fellow workers in Christ Jesus.

4.verse: They risked their lives for me, and I as well as all the Churches of the Gentiles am grateful to them.

5.verse: Greet also the Church that assembles in their house.Give my greetings to my beloved friend Epaenetus, who was the first convert to Christ in the province of Asia.

6.verse: Greet Mary, who has worked extremely hard for you.

7.verse: Greet Andronicus and Junia, my relatives who were in prison with me; they are eminent in the ranks of the apostles and were in Christ before I was.

8.verse: Greet Ampliatus, my beloved in the Lord.

9.verse: Greet Urbanus, our fellow worker in Christ, and my dear friend Stachys.

10.verse: Greet Apelles, who has proved worthy in the service of Christ, and those who belong to the family of Aristobulus.

11.verse: Greetings to my kinsman Herodion. Greet those in the Lord who belong to the household of Narcissus.

12.verse: Greet Tryphaena and Tryphosa who labor diligently in the Lord’s service. Greet my dear friend Persis, who also works hard for the Lord.

13.verse: Give my greetings to Rufus, one chosen by the Lord, as well as to his mother who has also been a mother to me.

14.verse: Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brethren who are with them.

15.verse: Greetings to Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, as well as all the saints who are with them.

16.verse: Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the Churches of Christ send you their greetings.

17.verse: Beware of Dissenters. -I urge you, brethren, to watch out for those who incite dissensions and obstacles in opposition to the teaching that you have learned. Take care to avoid them.

18.verse: For such people are not servants of our Lord Jesus Christ but of their own appetites, and by smooth words and flattery they deceive the minds of the simple.

19.verse: Your obedience has become known to all and has caused me to rejoice greatly over you. However, I want you to be wise in what is good and innocent in what is evil;

20.verse: then the God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.

21.verse: Greetings from Paul’s Companions at Corinth. -Timothy, my coworker, sends greetings to you, as do Lucius and Jason and Sosipater, my kinsmen.

22.verse: I, Tertius, who am writing down this letter, greet you in the Lord.

23.verse: Greetings also from Gaius, my host and the host to the whole Church, and from Erastus, the city treasurer, and our brother Quartus. [

24.verse: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.]

25.verse: Glory to God through Jesus Christ -Now to him who has the power to strengthen youin accordance with the gospel that I preachand the proclamation of Jesus Christ,according to the revelation of the mysterythat was kept secret for long ages

26.verse: but is now revealed,and through the prophetic writings is made known to all the nationsaccording to the command of the eternal Godto bring them to the obedience of faith—

27.verse: to God who alone is wise,through Jesus Christbe glory forever! Amen.
